div.p:
The business and
pleasures of London for this
year draw towards a conclu-
sion conclusion and our season for im-
improvement
which is the
business and the pleasure of this house
has begun - I do not mean
to remind you of a promise
but merely to say that our
house will for some time
be at our own disposal &
that none of us are engaged
from home

We cannot however refrain
from saying that the oftener
we hear from you, the more
we desire to see you

Mr dear Sir, My father flatters me that the
expression of my wish to see you here, may
add to the inducements by which he has endeavored
to draw you to Ireland - I can only repeat
the simple truth - that I do earnestly wish
to see in all the leisure of English domestic
intimacy one of whose abilities I have formed
such a high opinion, & of whose kindness &
friendship we have received so many proofs.

Your labors for the press are finished,
are they not? - You say you are not engaged
in politics - You are above making common
place excuses, especially to friends - then
what can prevent your coming to Ireland?
- Surely not the dread of 8 hours sea-sickness.
- The moment you land in Dublin you
can find a public mail coach as comfortable
as any in England, which will bring you to
our gate in one day's time - Or if you prefer
travelling by water we have a canal boat
which will bring you within 12 miles of us, where
our carriage should meet you - I enter into
detail because I have often known great schemes
fail for want of minor arrangements.
- you shall have complete leisure & command of your time.

My father is this day going to Dublin
to attend a Board of Education and to lay
before them a Plan for the education of the
poor in this country, which I know will
not be relished either by Bishops or Archbi
shops Archbshiops , but which I think you would approve
and which may perhaps please the liberal
part of the English public - but he and it w
be heartily abused in Ireland by the Pro
testant Protestant ascendancy party- and by a vast
majority who think that the people can be
driven best in the dark hoodwinked - Woe be to the coach-
men coachmen who persist in driving upon this belief
horses, who have now learnt their strength.

Come and converse with & we can go over
in five minutes more subjects than 5 hours
or 5 days writing could may comprise.
